what: Parse edges in a graph specification — parse_edgestring
title: Parse edges in a graph specification — parse_edgestring
text: Parse edges graph specification

title: Parse edges in a graph specification — parse_edgestring
Parse edges in a graph specification — parse_edgestring
text: edgestring single string containing set node-edge relationships edgelist vector node-edge relationships.

title: Parse nodes — parse_nodes
text: Parse nodes

title: Parse nodes — parse_nodes
text: edgelist vector node-edge relationships.

title: Generate a graph object — qd_dag
text: Provide simple syntax specifying paths nodes generate graph object.

title: Generate a graph object — qd_dag
code: qd_dag(   edgelist,   node_labs = NULL,   node_aes_opts = list(),   edge_aes_opts = list(),   format_special = TRUE,   verbose = FALSE,   check_dag = TRUE,   theme = "base",   ... )

title: Generate a graph object — qd_dag
text: edgelist vector node-edge relationships. node_labs named character vector containing label names. Defaults NULL. node_aes_opts list feeding aesthetic options nodes DiagrammeR::node_aes(). Defaults empty list. edge_aes_opts list feeding aesthetic options edges DiagrammeR::edge_aes(). Defaults empty list. format_special Render numeric elements alphanumeric alpha_id subcripts. Defaults TRUE. verbose Indicate whether print node edge dataframes console. See Details . Defaults TRUE. check_dag Logical. Check whether graph conforms rules DAGs. Defaults TRUE. theme Choose theme plot output. Defaults "base". Setting theme NULL use DiagrammeR's NULL attribute theme. ... Pass optional conditioned argument qd_themes().

title: Generate a graph object — qd_dag
text: Leaving verbose set TRUE may advisable ensure labels IDs mismatched. default, qd_dag() alphabetizes nodes included edgelist node_labs first assumption labels begin letter corresponding alpha_id, may always case.

title: Generate a graph object — qd_dag
code:
# Provide a list of edges, with nodes specified as letters or single words. edges <- c("A -> { B C } <- L",            "B -> C")  # make a DAG object and render the graph using the default theme g.obj <- qd_dag(edges) #>  #>  #> CHECKED: The diagram is a DAG.  DiagrammeR::render_graph(g.obj)  {"x":{"diagram":"digraph {

graph [rankdir = "LR",
       layout = "dot"]

node [shape = "plaintext",
      penwidth = "0.5",
      fontname = "serif",
      width = "0",
      height = "0"]

edge [arrowsize = "0.4",
     penwidth = "0.5"]

  "1" [label = "A", fillcolor = "#FFFFFF", fontcolor = "#000000"] 
  "2" [label = "B", fillcolor = "#FFFFFF", fontcolor = "#000000"] 
  "3" [label = "C", fillcolor = "#FFFFFF", fontcolor = "#000000"] 
  "4" [label = "L", fillcolor = "#FFFFFF", fontcolor = "#000000"] 
  "1"->"2" 
  "1"->"3" 
  "4"->"2" 
  "4"->"3" 
  "2"->"3" 
}","config":{"engine":"dot","options":null}},"evals":[],"jsHooks":[]} # Pass labels and aesthetic options for nodes or edges g.obj2 <- qd_dag(edges,                  node_labs = c("A" = "Alcohol",                                "B" = "BP",                                "C" = "CVD",                                "L" = "State"),                  node_aes_opts = list(shape = "plaintext",                                       fillcolor = "none",                                       color = "black"),                  edge_aes_opts = list(arrowsize = 0.5,                                       color = "gray"),                  theme = NULL) #>  #>  #> CHECKED: The diagram is a DAG.  DiagrammeR::render_graph(g.obj2)  {"x":{"diagram":"digraph {




  "1" [label = "Alcohol", shape = "plaintext", fillcolor = "#FFFFFE", color = "black", fontcolor = "#000000"] 
  "2" [label = "BP", shape = "plaintext", fillcolor = "#FFFFFE", color = "black", fontcolor = "#000000"] 
  "3" [label = "CVD", shape = "plaintext", fillcolor = "#FFFFFE", color = "black", fontcolor = "#000000"] 
  "4" [label = "State", shape = "plaintext", fillcolor = "#FFFFFE", color = "black", fontcolor = "#000000"] 
"1"->"2" [arrowsize = "0.5", color = "gray"] 
"1"->"3" [arrowsize = "0.5", color = "gray"] 
"4"->"2" [arrowsize = "0.5", color = "gray"] 
"4"->"3" [arrowsize = "0.5", color = "gray"] 
"2"->"3" [arrowsize = "0.5", color = "gray"] 
}","config":{"engine":"dot","options":null}},"evals":[],"jsHooks":[]}

what: Save graph objects as images — qd_save
title: Save graph objects as images — qd_save
text: qd_save() light wrapper around DiagrammeR::export_graph(), enables exporting high-quality /scalable graphics print online. convenience computational notebooks like quarto RMarkdown documents, qd_save() also allows user embed image via knitr::include_graphics().

title: Save graph objects as images — qd_save
code: qd_save(graph, file_name, ..., embed = FALSE, kg = NULL)

title: Save graph objects as images — qd_save
text: graph graph object produced qd_dag() file_name filename (possibly including path) save image. File type determined extension provided (pdf, svg, png, ps). See DiagrammeR::export_graph() details. ... Pass arguments DiagrammeR::render_graph(). embed Defaults FALSE. kg list allowing user set arguments knitr::include_graphics() (except path).

title: Save graph objects as images — qd_save
code: # redirect file to temporary directory (example only) file <- file.path(tempdir(), "dag.pdf")  # save without embedding dag <- qd_dag(c("L -> {A Y}", "A -> Y"),               check_dag = FALSE, verbose = FALSE) qd_save(dag, file)  # embed from code chunk using knitr::include_graphics() qd_save(dag, file, embed = TRUE) #> [1] "/tmp/RtmpnnzWF3/dag.pdf" #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "knit_image_paths" "knit_asis"         # `title` passed to DiagrammeR::export_graph() qd_save(dag, file, title = "Demo")  # clean up temporary directory file.remove(file) #> [1] TRUE

what: Generate a single-world intervention graph (SWIG) — qd_swig
title: Generate a single-world intervention graph (SWIG) — qd_swig
text: Take DAG graph object , simplest case, create single-world intervention template corresponding world fixed nodes set given value. Alternatively, tell qd_swig() values fixed nodes set .

title: Generate a single-world intervention graph (SWIG) — qd_swig
code: qd_swig(   graph_obj,   fixed_nodes,   custom_values = NULL,   fixed_sep = "vlin",   sep_point_size = 15 )

title: Generate a single-world intervention graph (SWIG) — qd_swig
text: graph_obj DAG object created qd_dag(). fixed_nodes vector containing nodes intervened upon. custom_values named vector containing alternative labels identifying explicit values fixed nodes (e.g., c("" = "1")). fixed_sep character string indicating character use separator fixed nodes. Defaults "vlin". Run sep_opts(TRUE) available options. sep_point_size numerical value specifying point size fixed node separators.

title: Generate a single-world intervention graph (SWIG) — qd_swig
code: # Provide a DAG object and a list of nodes to be fixed edges <- c("A -> Y", "L -> { A Y }") dag <- qd_dag(edges) #> #> #> CHECKED: The diagram is a DAG. swig <- dag |> qd_swig(fixed_nodes = "A", custom_values = c("A" = "1")) swig |> DiagrammeR::render_graph() {"x":{"diagram":"digraph { graph [rankdir = "LR", layout = "dot"] node [shape = "plaintext", penwidth = "0.5", fontname = "serif", width = "0", height = "0"] edge [arrowsize = "0.4", penwidth = "0.5"] "1" [label = | a=1 >, fillcolor = "#FFFFFF", fontcolor = "#000000"] "2" [label = a=1>, fillcolor = "#FFFFFF", fontcolor = "#000000"] "3" [label = "L", fillcolor = "#FFFFFF", fontcolor = "#000000"] "1"->"2" "3"->"1" "3"->"2" }","config":{"engine":"dot","options":null}},"evals":[],"jsHooks":[]}

title: Diagram themes — qd_themes
text: Apply various pre-fabricated themes diagrams.

title: Diagram themes — qd_themes
code: qd_themes(graph_obj, theme, ...)  theme_qd_base(graph_obj, font = "serif", ...)  theme_qd_circles(graph_obj, font = "serif", ...)  theme_qd_pearl(graph_obj, font = "serif", ...)  get_conditioned_nodes(graph_obj, conditioned = NULL)

title: Diagram themes — qd_themes
text: graph_obj DAG object created qd_dag(). theme character string indicating theme use. Defaults "base". Set NULL use GraphViz defaults. ... Pass arguments theme call (e.g., theme_qd_base()), conditioned font. font character vector indicating font family use node labels. Defaults "serif". conditioned character vector indicating nodes conditioned upon. shape nodes set "square".

title: Identify variables for adjustment — qd_todagitty
text: Format edgelist send dagitty identify variable adjustment sets.

title: Identify variables for adjustment — qd_todagitty
code: qd_todagitty(   edgelist,   diagram_type = "dag",   showplot = FALSE,   exposure,   outcome,   ... )

title: Identify variables for adjustment — qd_todagitty
text: edgelist vector edge relationships. Must strictly organized (see example format). diagram_type Character identifying diagram type. Defaults "dag", user can specify another graph type (see dagitty documentation). showplot Logical indicating whether produce dagitty plot. Defaults FALSE. exposure Character. Specify exposure interest. (Required) outcome Character. Specifiy outcome interest. (Required) ... Pass arguments dagitty::adjustmentSets(). See dagitty documentation options.

title: Identify variables for adjustment — qd_todagitty
text: exposure outcome options map dagitty functions name.

title: Identify variables for adjustment — qd_todagitty
code: edges <- c("A -> { B C D }",            "B -> C",            "E -> { B C }") # must pass exposure and outcome arguments to dagitty::adjustmentSets() qd_todagitty(edges, exposure = "A", outcome = "C") #>  {} qd_todagitty(edges, exposure = "A", outcome = "C", type = "minimal") #>  {}

what: quickdag: Make Beautiful Directed Acyclic Graphs — quickdag-package
title: quickdag: Make Beautiful Directed Acyclic Graphs — quickdag-package
text: package allows user save directed acyclic graphs (DAGs) generated DiagrammeR export PDF, PNG, SVG, PS format. Users may optionally choose view DAG without saving embed document. addition, quickdag allows user easily reformat DAGs single-world intervention graph (SWIG) templates.

title: quickdag: Make Beautiful Directed Acyclic Graphs — quickdag-package
text: Maintainer: Jason Gantenberg jason.gantenberg@gmail.com (ORCID)

what: View options for fixed node separator characters — sep_opts
title: View options for fixed node separator characters — sep_opts
text: Preview character options use fixed node separator SWIGs.

title: View options for fixed node separator characters — sep_opts
View options for fixed node separator characters — sep_opts
text: entity separator name HTML entity user's choosing. Defaults NULL. table Logical show hide HTML table display built-characters. Defaults FALSE.

title: View options for fixed node separator characters — sep_opts
text: default sep_opts() returns named vector listing built-separators. built-HTML entities attached nicenames convenience. user provides nicename built-entity entity argument, function return appropriate HTML code. user provides HTML entity appear built-menu, input returned verbatim. Users typically access latter functionality via qd_swig().
